pageContext.claim: “If you speak to the head of intelligence right now, you speak to the head, they did say that I was given a briefing when I said I was given it, not before. And they also said that it wasn't specific and it was not a panic briefing. It wasn't like, 'Oh, we're going to be invaded.' It was in January, later January.”
pageContext.analysis: Trump is referring to an oral briefing. But intelligence warnings about the coronavirus were contained in the President’s Daily Brief, a sensitive report that is produced before dawn each day and designed to call the president’s attention to the most significant global developments and security threats. "But the alarms appear to have failed to register with the president, who routinely skips reading the PDB and has at times shown little patience for even the oral summary he takes two or three times per week, according to the officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss classified material," the Washington Post reported.
